title: Add prompt detection heuristics for no shell integration command execution timeout
body:
This PR implements heuristic-based prompt character detection to improve command execution timeout handling when no shell integration is available, addressing the experimental idea outlined in #259564.

## Problem

The current `noneExecuteStrategy` uses a fixed 1-second timeout to determine when commands have finished executing. This approach has limitations:
- **Too short for long-running commands**: Commands that take longer than 1 second may be incorrectly considered complete
- **Too long for quick commands**: Fast commands that complete immediately still wait the full timeout
- **No context awareness**: The timeout doesn't consider whether the terminal is showing a prompt or command output

## Solution

Added intelligent prompt detection heuristics that extend the timeout based on terminal content analysis:

### Key Changes

1. **`detectsCommonPromptPattern()` function**: Detects common prompt patterns using regex:
   - PowerShell prompts (`PS C:\>`)
   - Command Prompt (`C:\path>`) 
   - Bash prompts ending with `$`
   - Root prompts ending with `#`
   - Python REPL (`>>>`)
   - Starship prompts (`❯`)
   - Generic prompts (`>`, `%`)

2. **`waitForIdleWithPromptHeuristics()` function**: Enhanced timeout logic:
   - Waits initial 1 second (maintains backward compatibility)
   - Reads terminal buffer around cursor position
   - If prompt pattern detected → completes immediately (faster)
   - If no prompt detected → waits additional 2 seconds (more reliable)

3. **Updated `noneExecuteStrategy`** to use the enhanced timeout logic

## Behavior Changes

**Before**: Always wait exactly 1 second regardless of terminal state
```
Command execution → Wait 1s → Continue (regardless of terminal content)
```

**After**: Intelligent timeout based on prompt detection
```
Command execution → Wait 1s → Check for prompt patterns
├─ Prompt found → Continue immediately (faster)
└─ No prompt → Wait additional 2s (more reliable)
```

## Examples

**Fast command with prompt**:
```
PS C:\> dir
Directory of C:\...
PS C:\> ← Prompt detected, completes after 1s
```

**Long-running command**:
```
PS C:\> npm install
Installing packages... ← No prompt, waits additional 2s
Still running...
```

## Testing

Added comprehensive unit tests covering all prompt patterns, multiline content, and edge cases. Manual validation confirms 100% accuracy for common prompt detection scenarios.

The implementation maintains full backward compatibility while providing better balance between speed and reliability for command execution detection.

Fixes #259564.

title: [Feature] Support merging user array settings with workspace settings instead of overriding

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: config
labels.description: VS Code configuration, set up issues

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
In certain cases it's disruptive that array settings are not merged, e.g. a workspace-specific config may be needed which disables all prior configuration, which is a) not transparent to the user that may have opened a third-party project, and b) cannot easily be circumvented short of putting all your user configuration into all workspace-specific files.

Example:
User Config:
```
"clangd.arguments": [
    "--header-insertion=never"
]
```
This is the only way to make clangd not automatically insert headers (that are often not relevant).
This should, in my opinion, stay in the user config.

I have multiple workspaces that share a folder among them. To make clangd work (using the workspace-specific compile-commands.json even for files in the shared folder) I need this in all workspace settings:
```
"clangd.arguments": [
	"--compile-commands-dir=${workspaceFolder}/../project_1/build"
]
```

Currently, any user opening these projects will find their own preferences broken.
To fix them, they need to manually copy their user preferences into ALL workspace settings (4 in my case).
In addition, with a project using git, having to keep local changes is a nightmare, since the workspace settings should NOT be listed in the .gitignore.
Really, there is no good solution to this as long as vscode just overwrites the user settings and doesn't merge the arrays.

I recognise that there is no perfect way to do this, especially since changing the default now might break existing setups.
Unless we're doing non-standard stuff like:
```
"clangd.arguments.add": [
    "--header-insertion=never"
]
```
which, when overriding or being overridden, marks the array for merging. Perhaps a different syntax is required.

Note: This has been requested prior to this: #151592

title: Run in terminal: Leverage child process monitoring as hint for whether commands are done
body:
The `NoneExecuteStrategy` (used when shell integration is not available) previously relied only on a 1-second idle timeout to determine when terminal commands were complete. This caused false positives where commands with child processes (like build tools, servers, or long-running tasks) were considered finished while sub-processes were still running.

This PR enhances the strategy by leveraging the existing child process monitoring infrastructure (the same logic that drives `terminal.integrated.confirmOnKill`) as an additional hint for command completion.

## Key Changes

**Enhanced Idle Detection Logic:**
- Wait for: `(data_idle AND no_child_processes) OR max_timeout`
- Monitors both terminal data events and child process state changes
- Uses adaptive timeouts based on initial terminal state

**Smart Timeout Strategy:**
- Clean terminal: up to 60 seconds for commands that spawn processes
- Already-busy terminal: up to 30 seconds (faster timeout to prevent hanging)
- Base idle detection remains 1 second for backward compatibility

**Pre-execution Checks:**
- Detects if child processes are already running before command execution
- Helps identify if the terminal is already busy with another command
- Provides better debugging information through enhanced logging

## Implementation Details

Added `waitForIdleWithChildProcessMonitoring()` function that:
- Listens to `ITerminalInstance.onDidChangeHasChildProcesses` events
- Delays completion when child processes are detected
- Always respects maximum timeout bounds to prevent infinite waiting
- Maintains event-driven architecture for responsive behavior

The strategy now completes when either:
1. Terminal is idle AND no child processes are running, OR
2. Maximum timeout is reached (prevents hanging)

## Backward Compatibility

When no child processes are present, the behavior remains identical to the original implementation. The enhancement only extends wait times when child processes are detected, making it safer without breaking existing workflows.

Fixes #259562.

title: Environment variables in mcp.json are resolved on host not devcontainer

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->

I have created a devcontainer that has a _mcp.json_ file in the _.vscode_ folder. In the _mcp.json_ file I configure the GitHub MCP server with PAT for the authentication like this:

```json
{
  "servers": {
    "github": {
      "url": "https://api.githubcopilot.com/mcp/",
      "type": "http",
      "headers": {
        "Authorization": "Bearer ${env:GITHUB_TOKEN}"
      }
    }
  },
  "inputs": []
}
```

In my Windows host system I have multiple GITHUB_TOKEN for different projects:
```
GITHUB_TOKEN=abc
GITHUB_TOKEN_A=def
GITHUB_TOKEN_B=ghi
```

I pass the environment variables to my WSL via this system environment variable:
```
WSLENV=GITHUB_TOKEN/u:GITHUB_TOKEN_A/u:GITHUB_TOKEN_B/u
```

I checked out the code in my WSL and started VS Code from the WSL.

The devcontainer.json has this entry for project A:

```json
  "remoteEnv": {
    "GITHUB_TOKEN": "${localEnv:GITHUB_TOKEN_A}"
  },
```

Opening the project in the container I see that:
- In a Terminal
    - `echo $GITHUB_TOKEN` produces the output __def__
    - `echo $GITHUB_TOKEN_A` produces an empty output, as it is not known in the container
- In the _mcp.json_ file 
    - `${env:GITHUB_TOKEN}` resolves to __abc__
    - `${env:GITHUB_TOKEN_A}` resolves to __def__ 

If I use `${env:GITHUB_TOKEN}` in a _task.json_ in the devcontainer _.vscode/tasks.json_, it resolves to __def__.

It looks like the mcp.json resolves the environment variables against the host and not the devcontainer as it should be. Of course I am not sure if the usage of environment variables in _mcp.json_ is officially supported as I didn't find any note about this. But the current behavior in combination with devcontainers seems inkonsistent to me.

title: Run in terminal: Re-write command _before_ checking auto approval

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: candidate
labels.description: Issue identified as probable candidate for fixing in the next release

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

body:
Repro:

1. Add `"ls": true` to `chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove`, make sure `cd` isn't there
2. Ask copilot: `Run in terminal: cd <cwd> && ls`, replace `<cwd>` with the current working directory of the workspace
3. It should show it without the `cd <cwd>`
4. It should run it automatically
5. Check the Terminal output channel for `info` logs to ensure that the command is being checked without the cd part as it was simplified

Impact:

Users will be confused about auto approve not working if they don't auto approve `cd`, causing trust to be lost in the feature.

title: Enable "New File..." menu entry for auxiliary windows
body:
Fixes the issue where the "New File..." menu entry was not available in auxiliary windows.

## Problem

The "New File..." menu entry (`welcome.showNewFileEntries` command) was only registered in the `MenubarFileMenu`, which is not the primary menu context used by auxiliary windows. Auxiliary windows primarily use `EmptyEditorGroupContext` and `EditorTabsBarContext` menus for file operations.

## Solution

This PR extends the menu registration to include auxiliary window contexts while maintaining the existing MenubarFileMenu registration:

1. **Added explicit enablement condition** to the existing MenubarFileMenu registration:
   ```typescript
   when: ContextKeyExpr.true()
   ```

2. **Extended menu registration** to auxiliary window contexts following the same pattern used by other file actions:
   ```typescript
   for (const menuId of [MenuId.EmptyEditorGroupContext, MenuId.EditorTabsBarContext]) {
       MenuRegistry.appendMenuItem(menuId, { 
           command: { id: 'welcome.showNewFileEntries', title: localize('newFileDialog', "New File...") }, 
           group: '1_file', 
           order: 5 
       });
   }
   ```

The implementation follows the exact same pattern used in `fileActions.contribution.ts` for registering file operations in these menu contexts, ensuring consistency with existing VS Code architecture.

## Testing

The changes are syntactically verified and follow established VS Code menu registration patterns. The "New File..." dialog should now be accessible via context menus in auxiliary windows.

title: Add opportunityId to context provider telemetry

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: candidate
labels.description: Issue identified as probable candidate for fixing in the next release

body:
VS Code writes telemetry about inline completions using a `opportunityId` as an identifier. To be able to correlate the telemetry with the TypeScript context provider the `opportunityId` should be added to the context provider telementry as well.

The `opportunityId` is forwarded by the Copilot client since the latest version.

title: Avoid 0ms interval rescheduling in configuration service
body:
Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259517

This change prevents an infinite loop of immediate scheduler execution when `ASSIGNMENT_REFETCH_INTERVAL` is set to 0 (meaning no polling should occur).

## Problem

The `ConfigurationDefaultOverridesContribution` class was unconditionally rescheduling its experimental settings scheduler, even when `ASSIGNMENT_REFETCH_INTERVAL` was set to 0. This caused:

- Infinite loop of immediate scheduler execution
- Potential performance issues
- Unbounded queuing of experimental settings processing

## Solution

Added a conditional check before rescheduling the scheduler:

```typescript
this.autoRefetchExperimentalSettingsScheduler = new RunOnceScheduler(() => {
    this.processExperimentalSettings(this.autoRefetchExperimentalSettings, true);
    if (ASSIGNMENT_REFETCH_INTERVAL !== 0) {
        // TODO@sandy081 wait for the promise returned by processExperimentalSettings to avoid unbounded queuing
        this.autoRefetchExperimentalSettingsScheduler.schedule();
    }
}, ASSIGNMENT_REFETCH_INTERVAL);
```

When `ASSIGNMENT_REFETCH_INTERVAL` is 0, the scheduler will run once but won't reschedule itself, properly implementing the "no polling" behavior.

Cherry-picked from commit d38eb0f3bbb0af3b0bf84ed6225da3c9127e753a by @hediet.

body:
RETARDET JOB MS CODERS

RafaelForrer: (ollama-chat39) PS C:\WEBAPPS\app.brainai.ch_x5>python app.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\WEBAPPS\app.brainai.ch_x5\app.py", line 3, in <module>
    from agents import AgentCoordinator
ImportError: cannot import name 'AgentCoordinator' from 'agents' (C:\WEBAPPS\app.brainai.ch_x5\agents\__init__.py)
(ollama-chat39) PS C:\WEBAPPS\app.brainai.ch_x5> 

Workspace: Collecting workspace informationThe error occurs because `AgentCoordinator` is defined in agents.py, not in the `agents` package. Your import in app.py should be:

````python
# ...existing code...
from agents import AgentCoordinator
# ...existing code...
````

Change it to:

````python
# ...existing code...
from agents import AgentCoordinator
# ...existing code...
````

````python
# ...existing code...
from agents import AgentCoordinator  # REMOVE THIS LINE

title: fix: position terminal icon picker dynamically based on trigger source
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

This PR fixes the placement issue with the terminal icon picker widget, as discussed in #211083.

✅ **Changes made:**
- Updated `TerminalIconPicker` so it now accepts a `source` parameter (`'commandPalette'` or `'terminalTab'`).
- The picker is now dynamically positioned:
  - **When triggered via the command palette**: appears centered below the command center.
  - **When triggered via the terminal tab**: appears near the terminal tab area.
- Adjusted `TerminalInstance.changeIcon` to call the picker with the correct source.

📌 **Why:**
Previously, the icon picker always appeared near the top center, which could look odd or be partially hidden.
This makes the UX more intuitive by placing the picker close to where it was triggered.

✅ **How to test:**
- Trigger the terminal icon picker via the terminal tab ➜ it should appear near the tab area.
- Trigger via the command palette ➜ it should appear centered below the command center.

---

**Fixes:** #211083  
✔️ Allows edits by maintainers

3. Run the `Open Chat in Editor` command.

body: - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 1.350.0 - VS Code Version: 1.102.3 - OS Version: Windows - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): - Logs: ## Description When using GitHub Copilot Chat in VS Code, the `"copy"` button that appears with generated code snippets works correctly in functionality — i.e., it copies the code — but there's `no visual feedback after clicking it`. This can confuse users who expect a "Copied! or Tick ✅" message. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Ask Copilot Chat to generate some code. 2. Click the `copy` button (top-right of the code block). 3. Notice that no visual change occurs. ## Expected Behavior: A small `tick icon or "Copied!"` text should temporarily replace the copy icon to confirm success. ## Screenshot

body:
You can use `"githubPullRequests.pullRequestDescription": "copilot"` to have copilot automatically generate the title and description for your PRs when you use the "Create Pull Request" command from the GitHub Pull Request description. 

In the GHPR, we use the string title of the title + description provider to tell which provider to use.

title: vscode opens the terminal to automatically execute the environment activation command, and opens the cmd window
body: When I open vscode to create a new terminal, he will always execute the conda activate xxx command by himself, and then jump out of the system's cmd terminal black box and then automatically close, not directly open my pre-selected environment , which causes me to wait for him to automatically execute the environment activation command every time I create a new terminal before proceeding to the next step, very slow, and sometimes the terminal will freeze, but this situation has not happened before. This is why, ask for an answer. I tried modifying the setting.josn file and trying to change the vscode version to the old version, but it didn't work. Specifically speaking，When I create a new terminal in VS Code, it first opens the base virtual environment, and then it automatically executes two commands. First, it runs D:/Anaconda/Scripts/activate, and then it automatically runs conda activate ML to activate the virtual environment preset for my code. Previously, when I used it, opening the terminal would directly activate my ML virtual environment without the two preceding command steps. I hope it will be like before, creating a new terminal that directly enters the preset environment without automatically executing the activation commands for those two environments, speeding up the terminal's performance. As shown in the picture:

title: [Feedback/Suggestion] The BYOK feature is critically undermined by the free chat quota
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->


Hello GitHub Copilot Team,

I am writing to provide feedback on the "Bring Your Own Key" (BYOK) feature and suggest a critical improvement.

### The Problem

The current implementation of the BYOK feature for external models (like Google Gemini) is tied to the standard GitHub Copilot free tier chat quota. When a user's free chat quota is exhausted (100%), any chat attempt using their personal API key fails mid-response with a "Canceled" error.

### Steps to Reproduce

1.  Configure Copilot (in an Insiders build) with a personal API key for an external model (e.g., Gemini 2.5 Pro).
2.  Use the standard Copilot chat until the monthly free quota is 100% exhausted.
3.  Attempt to start a new chat session using the model configured with the personal API key.
4.  **Expected Behavior:** The chat should function normally, as the cost of the API call is being handled by the user's own account.
5.  **Actual Behavior:** The response begins to generate and is then abruptly terminated.

### Why This is a Critical Issue

**1. It creates a deeply flawed user experience.**
An abrupt, mid-stream cutoff of a response feels like a bug or a system crash, not an intentional limitation. A well-designed quota system should ideally prevent the request from being sent in the first place, not terminate it halfway through a successful API call that the user is paying for.

**2. It defeats the entire purpose of the BYOK feature.**
The primary value proposition of BYOK is to empower users to leverage their own paid resources to bypass the standard plan's limitations. By tying BYOK functionality to the free quota, this core benefit is completely nullified. It creates a nonsensical "pay-twice" scenario:
*   You pay **Google/OpenAI/etc.** for the API calls.
*   You are *still* required to pay **GitHub** for a Copilot Pro subscription just to remove the session quota that blocks your own API calls.

This makes the BYOK feature redundant for the very users it's meant to empower.

### The Human Impact: A Student's Perspective

To provide a real-world example of who this affects, **I am a 16-year-old student from China.** I cannot afford the full Copilot Pro subscription.

I was incredibly excited when I heard about the BYOK feature, as I believed it would finally allow me to use these powerful AI tools for my learning and personal projects by using my own, limited API credits. The current implementation has unfortunately created a frustrating barrier where I thought a bridge was being built. It tells students and developers in similar financial situations that even if they are willing to pay for what they use, they are still locked out unless they buy the full subscription.

### Suggested Solution

**Please completely decouple the BYOK functionality from the GitHub Copilot free/pro tier quotas.**

Requests routed through a user's personal API key should not be subject to, nor checked against, Copilot's internal session quotas. The session management and quota logic for these external requests should be entirely independent, as the financial cost is borne by the user, not GitHub.

Thank you for your hard work and for considering this feedback. I believe this change would unlock the true potential of the BYOK feature and make Copilot a more accessible, powerful, and fair tool for the entire developer community, especially for students and independent learners around the world.

title: incremental history search for interactive windows
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Using "run current file in interactive window" I cannot find a way to recall search/filter previous history, as in a terminal session or iPython.  I know that I can use the up/down arrows to cycle through previous commands, but this is impractical if the command (or commands) I wish to retrieve are many tens of items up the history list.

In emacs or ipython or zshell, I'd use Ctrl-R and then start typing, and it finds previous commands matching what I type. Ctrl-R again cycles through history matching my string. [iPython docs](https://ipython.readthedocs.io/en/6.5.0/config/shortcuts/index.html) call this "Vi-style backward search", so I gather vi works this way too.

For example, I am accustomed to "ctl-r pri" only cycling through history items with a "pri" in them somewhere. Most of these will match "print(" statements. I find this quite useful to, for example, retrieve plotting commands after mucking around in the data.

Can I do this in the VS Code REPL environment?
